titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
I have received from Joseph Sturge, from Birmingham, England, a Letter in reply, to my Letter, of the 11th. of April, to him. It is dated the 6th. of this present month, since which, the Oregon Treaty, has superceded all necessity, for further correspondence, on that subject between him and me I received also a Letter from J. D. Reymert, dated at Boston 29 June inclosing a number of Engravings of Articles of Iron Manufacture, and a Catalogue of such articles, sold, by Wm. and C. Young, Manufacturing Iron Mongers and wire Merchants No. 123. High St. Edinburg and Glascow. Mr. Reymert is a Member of that House and recommends J. P. Robinson Esqr. as their Agent, in Boston. He encloses also Cards of the House and of J. P. Robinson He says they have received great encouragement, from several of the first Gentlemen, of the State and are using their endeavours for the extension of their business in this Country, and have for that purpose established several Agencies in the different principal Cities— I answered an invitation from E. B. Edwards Chairman of a committee of Whig Citizens of the County of Philadelphia, to a public Dinner on the Anniversary day next Saturday, declining as I had done to the invitation from the Whigs of the City of Philadelphia— At the House the debate on the Tariff Bill in committee of the whole on the state of the Union, again absorbed the day— James Thompson 23. Pennsylvania, finished his reply to Yancey whose excommunication from the Democracy he resented with much worthy indignation— R. M. T. Hunter 8. Virginia, hammered out, a common place, invective against protection and the tariff of 1842. R. Toombs. 8. Georgia made a pleasant, protection, tariff Speech. W. W. Wick of Indiana, a Speech on the other side. He said he was called by his Constituents, Billy Wick, and had once been a bit of a Federalist himself and was as honest then as he is, now which I readily believe: but now he was better informed. Charles H Carroll, 29. New York, supported
the tariff of 1842. and opposed the Bill— But David Wilmot 12. Pennsylvania, delivered a vehement Anti-tariff invective; immediately succeeded by Felix G. McConnell 1. Alabama to the same time “par nobile fratrum”— I left him speaking, and went and dined with Mr. Winthrop, Mr. & Mrs. Grinnell and the party at Mrs. Whitwells— It was passed six when I returned to the House where I found, Daniel M. Barringer, 2. North Carolina, speaking against the Bill, and in favor of the Tariff of 1842. Orlando. B. Ficklin 3. Illinois, and Joshua F Bell, 4. Kentucky, alternated for and against the Bill. Between 8. and 9. O’clock. Thomas Perry, 2. Maryland. took the floor, when wearied out, I left the House— I found my carriage, was not at the door, and making a mis-step, from the entrance of the Hall, I fell, and struck the left knee-pan, slightly bruising it, but not so as to disable me from walking— On coming out from the Capitol I met Thomas Dumphy with the carriage in which I returned home— Gardiner Fuller, our Coachman, left us yesterday returning to Boston, with his wife who is in the last stage of Consumption— I settled with him, for his wages, and took his receipt in full— I called this morning at the Bank of Washington for a Dividend, on City Corporation Six per cents but they had not received it from the City Hall—

George Green was here again this morning and I gave him a Letter from the Commissioner of Pensions to me, concerning the Claims of Sarah Clark and Catherine O’Neil together with their papers— The Commissioner calls for further testimony. Green insists, that their declarations contain, all
that the Commissioner requires, and complains much, of his decision, but he said he must submit to them, and thanked me, for the assistance I had given him on sundry of the Claims, for which he said “he was under a compliment to me” an expression which he often repeats, but which I never heard from any one else. By the word compliment, he means an acknowledgment of obligation— I wrote to Mrs. Macomb a note of acknowledgment and thanks, for her note to me, with the Georgetown Advocate of the 18th. June last, containing the Article written by her brother.— At the House, the Speaker took the Chair, precisely at nine. But there was a call of the House to make a quorum James McDowell 11. Virginia, moved to suspend the rules for a resolution, that after closing the debate in committee of the whole on the Tariff Bill at 2. P.M. this day members offering Amendments—should be allowed, to discuss them by remarks not exceeding fifteen minutes each; but the House refused to suspend the rules. I found Meredith P. Gentry 7. Tennessee speaking for the Tariff of 1842— Cobb the Chairman, next gave the floor, to George Ashmun. Rathbun 25. New York claimed against Cobb’s peremptory decision and Ashburn yielded; he thought that Rathbun would be ferocious; against the Bill which he was, but nevertheless, voted for it, just like Brinkerhoff of Ohio. Joseph R. Ingersoll 2. Pennsylvania, Moses Norris of New Hampshire and Jefferson Davis of Mississippi brought the debate to a close, at 2. P.M. Voting on Amendments then commenced and continued till seven when the committee rose, without concluding and the House adjourned to 10. to-morrow morning—

I received yesterday, a Letter from Wm. Tyson, for himself and Jonathan Seaver a Committee of the Society of Friends, requesting an interview with me, to obtain the Right of Way through my Land, near Rock Creek to the Grave Yard of the Society— I agreed to see him this morning, and he came— With his Letter there was a Diagram, of the Land, marking, the Road which is desired for the Way— I referred him to Mr Nathaniel Frye, who manages my real estate in this City and said that I was willing to have a survey made by a competent person or persons to lay out the way and estimate the value of the Land to be conveyed by me and I would execute the conveyance upon such terms as should be decided to be reasonable, by such Surveyor— I receive almost every day, Letters from strangers asking, for Documents, or Autographs or Money, loans from ten to five hundred dolls. I have a Letter from Curtis and Rall Cincinnati 13th. June 1846. making enquiries concerning certain Pension Claims for which I applied to the Office of the Clerk of the House, but no record of them was found— Christopher Hughes, came to the House and urged me, with friendly importunity, to with him, to Baltimore dine with the Society of Cincinnati, there to morrow go to Church with him on Sunday and return here on Monday morning in time for the Meeting of the House. But I perseveringly declined having no feeling for festivity to-morrow. In the House this whole day was consumed in voting upon Amendments, to the Tariff Bill, first in committee of the whole on the state of the Union, by Tellers, and after the Bill was reported with Amendments to the House, by yeas and nays— The struggle to strike out 20. per cent duty, on Tea and Coffee, was successful that to make salt free succeeded in Committee, but finally failed in the House; the fishing bounties, and
drawback on Salt, used in the Fisheries were carried in committee and restored in the House— The duty of 20. per cent on salt, was carried by the casting vote of the speaker, but there was a mistake of the Clerk, in counting the votes, and the speaker’s vote was nullified but a re consideration was carried, and the duty of 20. per cent made, a fixed fact all amendments proposing specific for ad valorem duties, were rejected— The new Bill levies 100 per cent upon spirituous liquors increased from 75. reported in the Bill of the Committee. Then came classes of Articles with forty, thirty, twenty, fifteen, ten, and five per cent— The Bill was finally passed by a vote of 114 to 95. All the democracy whipped in Tibbatts moved the reconsideration to clinch the Bill and the democracy sing “io triumphe.” Adjourned at six oclock P.M. over to Monday— Incessant showers throughout the day. I received an invitation from the Mayor and City Council of Boston to the Anniversary celebration, there to-morrow but supposed no answer necessary. The Senate yesterday passed by a vote of 32 to 13. the Bill, which had already passed the House retroceding the County of Alexandria to the State of Virginia— John Davis of Massachusetts voted for it Daniel Webster was absent. The Constitution of the United States is waste paper, and the District of Columbia was a delusion. The link of continuity to the Chain of this Union is shivered to atoms, and the next step will be the removal, of the Seat of Government to a Slave State— Notwithstanding the South Carolina slave monger John. C. Calhoun assured the Senate, there was no sort of danger of that, for it was proposed at the Memphis Convention and answered by a universal shout, No
Independence Day—

Seventy years since that day have passed. This from the time of the song of Moses is the average limitation of the life of man— The Pathé Celebrations recommended, and foretold by my Father, in his Letter to my mother of the 3d. July 1776. have been constantly held, and are still continued, throughout the Land. But in a succession of Anniversaries of a glorious day there seem in the process of time days of a far different character The 4th. of July has been made to me, by more than one incident, the saddest day of the year and among them is, that 20. years from this day it was the day of my Father’s death To others I need not refer— But yesterday was a day, of which I would gladly blot out the memory from the record of my life. In contemplating the future and approaching fortunes of my Country— This day was itself passed in comfortable tranquility, diversified by friendly visits from Mr. & Mrs. J. J. Crittenden and Mr. & Mrs. Joshua. F. Bell of Kentucky Mr. & Mrs. Kaufman of Texas, Mr. Wm. A Moseley of Buffalo, New York and Capt. John C. Casey in the evening— Mr. Nahum Capin of Boston was also here, with a Prospectus for the publication of a periodical Journal of Statistics; for which I subscribed— Dr. John M. Thomas, was here and informed us, of the sudden death of Mrs. Julia Maria Dickinson Tayloe, wife of Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, of this City. She fell in a fit, upon taking a shower bath, this morning.— She was the only daughter of the late John Dickinson of Troy New York, long a Member of Congress, and with whom, while he lived, and with his family including this Lady and her family, we have enjoyed a friendly and intimate acquaintance

At the Hall of the House of Representatives the Revd. Daniel Baker, formerly Minister of the 2nd. Presbyterian Church in this City and now of Holly Springs Mississippi, preached this morning from Matthew 28.6. “Come see the place, where the Lord lay”— The subject of course embraced a commentary, upon the crucifixion, and the Resurrection, topics, rather too massive, for Mr. Baker, to handle, without notes— Mr Baker discourses, much as he did in former days, but with more self confidence and more, as one having authority— He has grown fat— The Auditory was very thin, but the President, and Mrs. Polk, were there— About noon Dr. Thomas called, and mentioned, that at 4. o’clock this afternoon, there would be an informal funeral service, at the house of Mr. Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, over the remains, of his deceased wife, and that they would be immediately afterwards removed to the Railway Cars, and transported, to the residence of her mother, Mrs Dickinson at Troy in the State of New York— I accordingly attended, with my wife, Mrs. John Adams, and her daughter Louisa, at the house— A small company, of relatives and friends of the two families were there, and Mr. Pyne, after a short Address, to the Company assembled, read several of the appropriate prayers, from the Episcopal Prayer Book, after which he Coffin, was removed, to the Hearse, and carried, to the Railway Depot, of the Cars for Baltimore— Mr. Tayloe goes, with the remains—also Mr. Hubbard, a Member of the House from Connecticut, a Kinsman of Mrs. Tayloe. There was no procession of Carriages. Major Graham and Lieut Thom, were here this evening

I received a Letter from J. D. Clark, Elyria Loraine County Ohio, dated 1st. July 1846. and annexed to which is a Petition from William Ricke of Carlisle Township Loraine Co. Ohio, formerly ofVermont In as he states of John Ricke a warrior of the Revolution, and of the preceeding French War who died 5th. of August 1797. and left him Continental paper, Money Bills to the Amount of 196. 1/3. of which with interest he claims payment— This is the money, funded, by the system of Alexander Hamilton, at 100. for 1. and of which there are still parcel, in the possession of persons, simple enough, to claim payment, at their nominal value, with interest to this day— At the House, Edward. W. McGaughey 7. Indiana, moved an Amendment of the Journal, stating the facts, of the Speakers management, last Friday about the duty upon Salt, first made free, and finally saddled with a duty of 20. per cent— But the Speaker had suppressed all that part of the proceedings, as Null and void.— He ruled McGaughey’s motion out of Order. McGaughey appealed from his decision, Cobb moved to lay the Appeal on the Table, which was carried 90. to 52.— Jacob Brinkerhoff, asked to make a personal explanation, for which, he obtained a suspension of the rules— Explanations from him, W. W. Wick, and from George Rathbun— A Letter from Wick, dated 12. of June, and published in a Western Newspaper, occasioned much diversion— He boasted of his intention to pummel the New York Loco Foco’s and whip them in to the Democratic ranks, which he did and at which Rathbun, was very indignant— All ending in smoke, and a silly epigram from Washington Hunt— Augustus Dodge Delegate from the Iowa Territory presented a new Constitution in that State, adopted in May 1846. Not the same, as that presented last year— It was ordered to lay on the Table. The Select Committee, on the Public printing of Congress
presented majority and minority Reports. Upon which there was debate, between Henley of Indiana Garrett Davis of Kentucky and Benton of New York— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Orlando. B. Ficklin of Illinois Chairman on the Bill to reduce and graduate price of Public Lands: that is to say to give them away— A skirmishing debate followed Brodhead, of Pennsylvania, and Hoge of 6th. Congressional District of Illinois, offered joint resolutions for closing the Session, on the 27th. of this Month— A Message from the President was received, transmitting copies, of the correspondence, with the Governor of New York; in the case of McLeod— McKay reported war appropriation Bill and Treasury note Bill Adjourned about four oclock.

Mid-Summer weather sets in, very intense— I received a Letter from Charles. A. Davis New York 3. July, 1846. Some what modifying his new, low Tariff doctrine of counteracting Foreign cheapness of labour, by internal facilities of transportation— A new theory. Also from George. M. Justice Philadelphia urging, the importation of Telescopes, for learned Institutions duty free— From M. J. Grove Fredricksburg Lebanon Co. Pennsylvania—3. July 1846. An Iron monger, enquiring my opinion whether the Tariff of 1842, will be modified— He says if it is, his occupation will be gone— Received also a Sermon of War, by Theodore Parker, Minister of the 28th. Congressional Church in Boston delivered 7. June 1846. The Protestant Quarterly Review, and George H. Coltons American Review with a Portrait of Daniel Webster, both for July 1846— At the House Ashmun moved, to amend the Journal
by inserting in it, at full length the Motion yesterday, made by McGaughey. The Speaker decided Ashmun’s motion not in order— Joseph Hoge, 6 Illinois this morning modified his joint resolution to close the Session on the 3d. of August instead of the 27th. this month— The rules were suspended to receive his resolution—on which he moved the previous question— The House refused to lay it on the Table 59. to 105, and the resolution was carried, but Andrew Stuart moved a reconsideration to propose an earlier day of adjournment, say the 20th. inst— Long and desultory debate, till Stuart withdrew his motion for reconsideration and Hoge himself renewed it whereupon the Question was postponed to this day two weeks— The Land graduation Bill was debated in committee of the whole on the state of the Union till there was no quorum Then came a Call of the House and an anarchy of two hours and a half— The call did not procure a quorum. The absentees were not sent for as by the rule they should have been, but McKay moved a resolution that they should be required to account for their absence, at the meeting of the House tomorrow morning—or when they should first resume their seats— The speaker pronounced this motion out of order, but the majority present, reversed his decision— At half past six they adjourned without obtaining a quorum— We had evening visits from Mr. Healey, Major Graham, Lieut Thom, Mr. & Mrs. Stockton with Miss Mary McKnight

8. IV.30. I received a Letter from my son to his Mother dated1846. and accounts for delay in writing hitherto from the excess of his occupations— He has undertaken to by the Editor
of the Boston Daily Whig newspaper. I fear too heavy a task. I received also, the July number of Redwood Fischer’s National Magazine and a concise view of Oregon Territory &c by Elijah White. Also Wesley and Putnam’s Library News Letter and Monthly Register of New Books Foreign and American. published on the 1st. of every month at 165 Broadway New York. July 1846. Volume 5 no. 56. This is a very valuable, Monthly notice of new publications— At the House, two hours were again consumed, in reversing the proceedings of less than a quorum yesterday to compel the attendance of the absent Members— The Absentees then, were now the majority of a bare quorum, and they nullified the reversal by the majority yesterday, of the Speaker’s decision that the Motion of McKay, requiring the Absentees to account this morning for their absence yesterday, was not in order— Tibbatts moved to expunge from the Journal, all the proceedings of the less than quorum yesterday— This failed, but the reversal of the Speakers decision against McKay’s motion, was now reversed, and all the proceedings with the call, annulled— McKay moved, to suspend the rules, for him to offer two new rules, one to enter the names, of the Absentees upon lack of a quorum in committee of the whole, upon the Journal, and the other to publish them in the newspapers The House refused to suspend the rules 71. to 86. Robert Dale Owen, asked leave to introduce a Bill to free from postage all correspondence with the Army of occupation— Refused— Haralson, from the Military Committee asked leave to report a Bill granting Land to the Soldiers and Volunteers of the Army, refused Committee of the whole on the state of the Union
Orlando. B. Ficklin 3. Illinois, Chairman on the Land graduation Bill— Speeches by Collamer Henley, Vinton, and Gordon, Committee rose at 1/2 past 3. the House adjourned— I took an evening walk and heard the Music, on the grounds of the President’s House. Met Waddy Thompson there and many others.

I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis a check for $112.50. received yesterday at the Bank of Washington a Quarterly Dividend with interest on City Corporation 6. per cent stock $7,500.— Nathaniel Chick 86 years old, and a pension Claimant of the Revolutionary and last English War came with a man named Donovan, to ask for my assistance— I took his papers to the Pension Office and this evening received from the Commissioner, J. L. Edwards, a report, rejecting his claim as spurious— At the House Alvan Cullom 4. Tennessee moved to consider a motion made by him, to print an extra number of the report from the Committee of Foreign Affairs the Volunteer War Manifesto against Mexico Lost. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Ficklin Chairman, Land graduation Bill from the Senate, opposed by Samuel Gordon 10. New York, and ably, by Robert. C. Schenck, 3. Ohio—but dragooned along by W. W. Payne of Alabama. The Bill from the Senate was brought just as Schenck finished his Speech, Against that of the House, whereupon the Committee rose the Bill from the Senate was immediately referred to it, the House went into committee again and the Senate Bill was substituted for debate— The object of both Bills being the same, to give away
away the Public Lands, to poor men, declaring themselves so, under the name of graduation and reduction of price— Cornelius Darragh, 21. Pennsylvania, opposed the Bill, and Jacob Thompson of Mississippi, Samuel. F. Vinton 12— Ohio, took the floor. John A McClernand, 2. Illinois, moved to close the debate at noon to-morrow— Adjourned without taking the question— The heat was so intense that I was compelled to intermit my evening walk and to languish for my old Potomac Baths, which I must renounce for age—

I received a discourse on the Life and character of Sir Walter Raleigh, delivered before the Maryland Historical Society 19th. May 1846. the third annual address to that association by J Morrison Harris; and a Letter from Thomas S. Donoho, of enquiries, about the last line of the Sonnet to the Sun eclipsed and beclouded, on the 25th. of April 1846. Misprinted and made perfect nonsense, in a New York Newspaper. When I began to write that Sonnet at my seat in the House, while the eclipse, was in its passage, Mr. Thomasson of Kentucky passing by my Seat saw me writing it, and observing the words “to the Sun eclipsed” followed by some verses, his curiosity was excited, and he asked me, for a copy of it to send to his daughter— I accordingly gave him a copy, which was seen by a reporter for the Courier and Enquirer and sent to that City— But he murdered the last line by writing it

lg.l: “Such dire eclipse and transient cloud obscures.”

div.p: instead of

lg.l: Each dim eclipse, or transient cloud, obscures.

div.p: And so, it was published, in the New York Courier and Enquirer, and from that, in several other newspapers, much to the amazement of Mr. Thomas. S. Donoho, and of course quite unintelligable to him, and to all other readers— So much for dealing in Poetry. At the House, McClernands motion to close debate on the Land graduation Bill, modified from noon, to 2. P.M. this day, was adopted and they went immediately into Committee Vinton spoke with the voice of the charmer to the adder. Brockenbrough of Florida, R. Chapman, of Alabama, Dodge, the Delegate from Iowa, Stephen Adams of Mississippi all worthy Representatives of the Anglo-Saxon Land-robber, answered Vinton, and of course abused him for his honesty— James. McDowell of Western Virginia had but five minutes to offer a substitute Bill of his own. At the voting commenced Houston of Alabama, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, and Darragh of Pittsburgh, offered amendments, to give away the Lands to poor men, maids or widows, 60. Acres each— John. H. Ewing 20. Pennsylvania white or black. Andrew Stuart, moved to give 500000. Acres of Land to each of the Old States. All these amendments were rejected. Sam. Gordon moved to lay the Bill on the Table; which was rejected on the question of engrossment of the Bill for a third reading the vote was 84. to 98. and the Bill was rejected— But Daniel of North Carolina immediately moved a reconsideration— McClernand of Illinois asked what was his motive, he answered to amend the Bill which was clear enough without needing enquiry— The vote upon reconsideration was 89. to 89. The Speaker gave the casting vote in its favor— Adjourned 81. to 80. Intense heat— Evening visit from James. D. Westcott one of the Senators from Florida.

I enter upon my eightieth year—with thanksgiving to God, for all the blessings, and mercies, which His Providence has bestowed upon me, throughout a life extended now to the longest term alloted to the life of Man— With supplication for the continuance of those blessings and mercies, to me and mine, as long, as it shall suit, the dispensations of His wise Providence, and for resignation to His Will, when my appointed time shall come— On going to the House this morning I ordered my Coachman, Thomas Dumphy to come with the Carriage for me at 1/2 past 3. oclock, expecting the House would adjourn about that time— But they adjourned before 2. I went into the Library, and amused myself by looking over Books and Engravings; till 1/2 past 3— I met there Mr. John Connell and several others— I then left the Capitol, and soon met the carriage in which I returned home— At the House the first question that arose, was upon a call of the House, moved by George Rathbun, and upon which, after a second call of absentees, 177. Members answered to their names— I arrived in time to answer to the 2d. call. The Land graduation Bill, from the Senate, was still before the House after having been once rejected, and restored by reconsideration— Cobb of Georgia had moved a substitute, upon which Collamer of Vermont, moved to lay the Bill on the Table— Which was carried by yeas and nays 92. to 87. and Samuel Gordon, immediately moved a reconsideration of that vote. The vote for reconsideration was 91. to 90— The motion to lay the Bill on the Table was lost 89. to 91.— Private Calendar was taken up and several private Bills passed. McKay, gave notice that he would next Monday, call up that Bill for the issue of Treasury notes and the loan, and the House adjourned.

The continued intense heat of the Season, has produced, a personal debility, which I never before knew.— I feel, like a living ruin with the power of vital agency extinct; a plant withered at the root, a tree, dying downward from the top. I feel above all the want of a bath and was disappointed last evening, in going to the Public hot baths of this City, to be told that they had no hot water—but could have some if I would wait half an hour. Which however I declined— There was no preaching this at the Hall of the House of Representatives of which notice was given in the National Intelligencer of yesterday, and the reason assigned for it was that the Chaplain of the Senate Mr. Tustin, whose turn it was to officiate was indisposed. Of Mr Milburn the Chaplain of the House, no account was given. I attended Church this morning at St John’s with my Grandaughter Mary Louisa— My wife and Mrs. John Adams, were not well; unable to attend— Mr. Pyne read the Service for the fifth Sunday after Trinity, and preached, from Psalm. 38.18. last clause of the verse, “I will be sorry for my Sin”— At five in the afternoon I attended again at the same Church, alone. Mr. Pyne read the evening Service of the day, and preached from 1. Corinthians 9.26. last clause of the verse, “So fight I not as one that beateth the air.” Mr. Pyne’s discourses are ingenious, argumentative, and well seasoned, with the benevolence, if not with the humility of the Christian faith Mr. Pyne’s Christian, must be sorry, according to the rubric of the Church, and must expect pardon for his sins, through her intercession. I closed the day, as it had begun with resignation— I attempted to read, in The Philosophy of the plan of Salvation, but gave it up. Tried a few pages of Sarto resartus. The evening melted away without leaving a trace behind.

I rose this morning with the dawn, and drawn by an irresistible impulse walked over the lower Tiber bridge, to my old bathing spot, on the margin of the Potomac—and there, under the shelter of the high bluff yet remaining, I bathed and swam, from five to ten minutes, came out, dressed myself, and walked home. As I went down the Hill, to the edge of the water, I found three young men, neither of whom I knew, already in the river, and heard one of them say, there is John Quincy Adams— They had their clothes, at one of my old standard rocks, but without noticing or disturbing them, I found another rock, a few rods higher, towards the Potomac bridge, where I left my clothes. The tide was low, and the time not convenient, for entering the river, but I succeeded, in obtaining the bath, for which I panted— The time consumed, was as in former days, about one hour and a half—half an hour going to the river, 1/2 and hour to bath, swim, and dress, and half an hour to return— The Thermometer was at 84. the water warm, the atmosphere calm, and the Sun clear— The exercise, washing, the sensation of personal cleanliness, were as of old, but the nervous agitation throughout the day, was not sensibly relieved and the weariness of the evening, threatened a restless night— Francis Richmond, was here, with Thomas. L. McKennie Memoirs—about Indians. 2. Octavo Volumes, in one, of which I took a Copy— And Father Green, with papers of W. Roberts, which he wished me to deliver, to Preston King, Chairman of the Committee on Invalid Pensions—which I did— At the House, Hugh. A White 16. New York, moved for a Select Committee of five, to examine the accounts, of the 5th. Auditor Pleasonton, but the House refused, to suspend the rules, to receive his motion.— George— C—
Dromgoole, of 2d. Congressional District Virginia moved a message to the Senate; to remind them, of four Bills, passed by the House and sent to them, and to recommend their action upon them— A very unusual Message, not without example, in both Houses of the British Parliament, once, practised by the Senate of the United States, to the House, much to their indignation— The vote to suspend the rules, for Dromgoole was 39. to 72. Among the Bills of which he wished to remind the Senate, was that commonly called the River and Harbour Bill. One or two of Dromgoole, Party associates, enquired why, he had omitted that, from his memento— He said he had included four Bills, and that he thought sufficient— Several Bills from the Senate were passed or referred to Committees Harralson, reported a Bill, for granting Lands to the Soldiers. Numerous other reports from Committees were received. Sawyer moved to suspend the rules, for a call on the President for the correspondence, on the Oregon Treaty. Refused, without even allowing the yeas and nays. Land graduation Bill was taken up Call of the House—173. answered— McKay moved an amendment to the Bill and Cobb an amendment upon that. Cobbs amendment was rejected 87. to 95. and McKay’s 88. to 93. Motion to lay the Bill on the Table, 90. to 89. The Speaker voted made a tie and the motion was lost, moved again and lost 91. to 92, and again 86. to 92. Rathbun moved to adjourn which was carried 89. to 85—

Second day’s Bath, and swim, in the Potomac, the weather still continuing at intense Summer heat. The success of these experiments, is doubtful, but my repose of the last night was not unsettled, but rather
improved, by the bath, of yesterday— At the first Meeting of the House the Stern chase of re-considerations, was renewed— The Amendment moved by Cobb, and the Amendment of that moved by McKay after being both rejected, had both been re considered. The previous question on the Land graduation Bill had been ordered, and McKay had moved to reconsider that; he now withdrew this motion, and moved a Call of the House, which the Speaker pronounced not in order— Truman Smith, as a back-handed Call of the House moved to adjourn, and asked for the yeas and nays—which were 6. to 163. Schenck moved to reconsider this vote but the Speaker decided that a motion to adjourn could not be reconsidered Schenck appealed from this decision, and stood alone in his glory McKay’s Substitute for Cobbs Amendment was then adopted 96. to 86. and McKay’s Bill substituted for that of the Senate, was passed 92 to 90— Ewing of Pennsylvania, inquired of the Speaker, whether every Member, present in his Seat, was not bound to vote? The Speaker said, that by the rule of the House, he was, but that very frequently Members did abstain from voting without notice from the House. Ewing replied that his Colleague Charles. J. Ingersoll was in his Seat, but did not vote, on the passage of this Bill— A motion to reconsider was made pro forma and laid on the Table. Sundry Bills were received from the Senate, among which one for the relief of Elizabeth Widow of Alexander Hamilton— Hoge, Illinois, moved to lay it on the Table—lost 69. to 81— The Bill was referred— A Bill for the improvement of the Ohio, Missouri, Mississippi and Arkansas, inland Seas, a notable device
of the political Mountabank John. C— Calhoun, came next— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine, moved to lay it on the Table— The Speaker said, that on the first reading of a Bill if opposed, the only question was shall the Bill be rejected—whereupon Hamlin moved that it be rejected, Rathbun moved the previous question, carried. Jacob Thompson moved a call of the House—the Speaker said it was too late, the previous question having been seconded. The main question was ordered, Tibbatts moved to adjourn and asked for the yeas and nays which were refused, and also the motion to adjourn— The question, shall the Bill be rejected, was taken by yeas and nays, 120. to 48. a majority formed by the sense, of the House that the Bill itself was a swindlers trick— McClelland of Michigan, moved a re-consideration and the previous question, the reconsideration was refused without division— The Treasury Note and loan Bill, was then taken up, in committee of the whole, on the State of the Union. Samuel Gordon Chairman, Garrett Davis offered an Amendment, and discussed the Mexican War, Tilden, Giddings Thurman, of Ohio and Douglass of Illinois racketed the lie, that the War began by the Act of Mexico— Tibbatts took the floor, and the committee rose— McKay moved a resolution, to close the debate, on the Treasury Note and loan Bill, in Committee of the whole to-morrow at noon. The House adjourned without taking, the question The decisive vote of the House, upon the Western River Bill, from the Senate, indicates some indignation, at the attempt, to appropriate monies, for Southern Rivers, to the exclusion of all others—

Third bath and swim in the Potomac at five oclock this morning, still with a clear sky, and a bright rising Sun, but with a fall of ten degrees of Fahrenheit’s from 84. to 74—and a brisk breeze ruffling the surface of the river, so that when I came out, I shivered while dressing at my old rock, but warmed in walking home and suffered no after inconvenience. Nathaniel Chick was here again this morning—86. feeble, tottering at death’s door— I took his papers, to the Pension Office, and entreated the commissioner Edwards, to re-examine them, & reconsider his decision— He sent them back to me this evening with a Letter saying that he has no confidence in them, and sees no evidence that Chick is entitled to a Pension for Service, either in the War of the Revolution or in the last War, with England— He considers Chicks Statements as false, and says they are at variance, with notorious Historical facts; but does not specify in what that variance consists at the House McKay’s motion, to close debate, on the Treasury note and loan Bill at noon this day, was adopted— Garrett Davis, Stanton of Tennessee, Graham of North Carolina, moved amendments which were rejected, as was an additional section moved by Andrew Stuart— Joseph. R. Ingersoll, moved an appropriation of $50,000. to pay certain old Treasury Notes, once paid, but stolen and reissued at New Orleans— This was carried, and the Bill passed 118. to 47. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Norris Chairman— Volunteer appropriation bill—$16.347.000. the estimate. $12000000 appropriated. Garrett Davis, Thurman, Rathbun, Vinton, J. J. McDowell, Henley and Houston of Alabama debated the Bill, and the Mexican War—
Solomon Foot, took the floor, the committee rose and the House adjourned. I walked, this evening in the Grounds of the Presidents House, and heard the Music.— I met there Mr. John. A. Rockwell, Member from Connecticut, who came home with me, and took tea with us.

Fourth bath, and swim, in the Potomac— Water and atmosphere cold, but smooth with a clear sky. The effect of this exercise, and ablution upon my health, is yet somewhat doubtful.— The tides is still rising, but not yet, high at five in the morning— Mrs. Burnet of Cincinnati, and her son, were here as visitors— Nathaniel Chick, came again— I could only tell him, of the inflexibility, of the Commissioner of Pensions, Edwards— But as a last resource, I offered to go with him to the Office, He said he was so feeble, that he prefered waiting till tomorrow morning, when he would call on me again for that purpose; to which I agreed— At the House the day began, by an explanation of Tibbatts repelling, attacks upon him by Stanton of Tennessee, and Billy Wick of Indiana— McKay, from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a Supplemental Appropriation Bill, for the pay of Members of Congress, and for the Indian Department, a coincidence, with which Dromgoole, made merry insisting that in this association the Congressmen must be provided for first— Joseph. R. Ingersoll, moved a joint resolution, authorizing and requesting the President, to cause Medals to be struck from the trophies of the Battles of Palo Alto and Resaca de la Palma, to be distributed to every individual engaged in them, which was carried without opposition— McKay moved a resolution to close the debate on the additional
Army Appropriation Bill at 2. P.M. this day, which was adopted, though Ashmun moved to lay it on the table— Cranston presented resolutions of thanks, of the Legislature of Rhode Island, to General Taylor, for the victories of the 8. and 9th. of May— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Norris Chairman on the additional Army Appropriation Bill— The precise amount appropriated, is $11.812.015.09. to support 25000 Volunteers for the year and additional Officers to the Army Debated by Foot, Caleb. B. Smith, Hilliard Cobb, and others.— Reported to the House without amendment and passed 160. to 4. of whom I was one— A joint resolution came from the Senate, to adjourn the Session on the 10th. of August, which was immediately adopted— The Bill to provide further Supplies, for Congressmen and Indians, was resumed in Committee of the whole on the state of the union, John Wentworth Chairman A tumultuary and burlesque debate, followed till about four oclock, when the Committee rose, in utter confusion and inextinguishable laughter, and the House adjourned—

Fifth bath and swim, between four and five oclock in the morning in the Potomac. This day Thomas Dumphy, went with me— The weather cool and cloudy, the river smooth and the water cold the time of tide beginning to serve. Returned—along the strand—from which all the old trees have been Swept away by the encroaching tides, and by the border of the Tiber— Nathaniel Chick came again but still wished to postpone going with me to the Pension Office— He said he had written to the Governor of Pennsylvania, for a Certificate
of character and wished to wait for his answer. I observe he is unwilling to be confronted, with Mr. Edwards. I took him with me, to his lodgings at Donovons next to the Railway Depot— Mr. Kavasales was here, still without a favourable decision from the Secretary of the Navy, notwithstanding the energetic interposition of Mr. Rathbun. Mr. Giddings went yesterday on a short tour to Boston and Portland. At the House, the day was devoted to the Private Callendar— Sundry reports from Committees were received, and variously disposed of. The House then took up the Bills, heretofore reported from the committee of the whole, and what with motions, to lay Bills on the table, adopted or rejected as if by lot, with motions to reconsider, carried and postponed, with calls of the House to make a quorum adopted and superseded with motions to adjourn repeated and rejected 49. Private Bills were passed, and sent to the Senate for concurrence. The vote to lay the Bill for the relief of William Pool on the table was adopted and reconsidered; but when the Question on the passage of the Bill came, there was no quorum voting and about three the House adjourned— I commenced my walk homeward and met, with a young man named, I think Derry?, from Cincinnati; a painter, who he said was going to Europe, for improvement in his profession, and for whom he requested from me Letters of introduction, to any of my friends— I met the carriage, with Thomas Dumphy and rode part of the way in Pennsylvania Avenue but he had to stop, at a shop whereupon I got out, and walked home I began this morning to read the Psalms, five every day—

There was rain in the night and this morning was cloudy and cold— I concluded therefore reluctantly to intermit my river baths— I received an invitation from Mr. Mullady President of the Georgetown College to attend at their Commencement on Tuesday the 28th. instt. at 1/2 past nine oclock A.M. but it interferes with the sitting of the House, for which reason I shall not be able to attend— At the House, sundry Bills were received from the Senate, and referred to Committees. The consideration of private Bills occupied the remainder of time till the adjournment, at three. First in committee of the whole Thomas Butler King Chairman, and then, in the House. Among the Bills taken up was that for the relief of the Heirs of Robert Fulton, an appropriation of $76.300. to be paid them, in full of all his claims. Reported by Robert C. Schenck from the Committee of Naval Affairs—when the Bill came up Schenck the reporter, was not in the House, and several attempts were made, to pass over the Bill to defeat it— Mr. Connell was in the passage way to the House in great distress, and consternation— Orvil Hungerford 19. New York, moved to strike out $76.300. and insert $16.300— Lost. Samuel Gordon moved to insert $20.000. which the Chairman pronounced not in order, but the Committee reversed his decision. Gordon then modified his motion to insert $40.000. Joseph. J. McDowell quoted a Speech of Silas Wright in the Senate against the Claim, which I answered Rathbun moved to report the Bill with recommendation to reject it— Lost— I moved to rise and report the Bill— Carried— Passed to a third reading by yeas and nays 90 to 67. and passed. Reconsideration refused— I had
a visit from Mr. Perry of South Carolina, son of a man, who many years ago, migrated to that State from Sherburn, Massachusetts, he is now going to inquire, for Kindred of his own name. Evening visit from our neighbour Mr. Buchanan—Secretary of State—

The Revd. E. Yulee, of Woodward College Cincinnati Minister of the New Jerusalem Church and brother of the Senator from Florida, performed the Service of Public Worship in the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning. He is an Israelite converted to Swedenborg Christianity— He read some passages from the Bible made a short and fudged prayer, gave out by two lines at a time to be sung the hymn

lg.l: “With one consent let all the earth,
To God their cheerful voices raise”

div.p:
read the 53d. Chapter of Isaiah, and delivered a cold address of half an hour, upon the 4th. verse of that Chapter—“Surely he has bourne our griefs, and carried our sorrows, yet we did deem him striken, smitten, of God, and afflicted”— Upon this text, he engrafted the Doctrine, and material and spiritual correspondencies, so as to make it, more unintelligible, than it is by Swedenborg himself— There were not more than fifty persons, in the Hall, and among them was his brother, the quandam David Levy, with his wife, who spoke with him after the service was over— I received a pamphlet, on this correspondence, of natural things to spiritual, by Thomas H. Perry Professor of Mathematics in the United States Navy— At five this afternoon, I went to Saint Johns church, but found all the
doors closed—there was no evening Service, there. I read the first, of the Revd. Daniel Bakers Revival Sermons, on the truth, and excellence of the Christian Religion— Mr. Baker, is an excellent, and very amiable man, not very profound—as a reasoner. He complains, that Infidels, are not satisfied, with reasonable evidence, but we must at last recur, to faith. Mr. Moseley, Member of the House, from Buffalo New York, made us an evening visit, as also Mr. Larned, Mrs. Newman, Mrs. Talbot, and her daughter Mary— My health and spirits, very much drooping.

The time for the morning bath, in the Potomac now suits exactly, for five oclock in the morning but I am discouraged, by admonitory symptoms, following upon my baths of the last week and dare not repeat them. I met at the Capitol Mr. Healey the Painter, and went with him, to Plumbe’s Gallery, where they took two, Daguerreotype full-length likenesses, of me. Both very indifferent Mr. Healey wanted to introduce me as a spectator into the Historical Picture of Daniel Webster answering Robert Y. Hayne in the United States Senate on Footes Resolution in 1831—which picture he is to paint for certain Whigs of Boston to be suspended in Fanuel Hall I told Mr. Healey, that I must decline being introduced into that picture, not having been at that time, in the Senate, nor in public Life at all, nor present in the Senate chamber at the scene I was residing in this City in private life from 3d. March 1829. until December 1831. when I first took my Seat as a Member of the House of Representatives— Healey told me that he was engaged also, to paint an Histor
ical Picture of John. C. Calhoun, in some Oratorical attitude as a counterpart, to this illustration of Daniel Webster, to be hung up somewhere at Charleston South Carolina, and that these two works, would be henceforth, a great labour of his life— He said he should leave this City next Thursday—and after stopping at Philadelphia, to paint a copy of Inman’s portrait of Chief Justice Marshall, he should proceed to Boston and embark, in the Steamer of the 16th. of August to return to France, and after thus accomplishing, his Commission from King Louis Phillipe, he intends to come back here, to execute his two great Historical pictures. I met Judge Burnet at Plumbe’s— He was a Member of the Senate at the time of Foote’s resolutions, and is to form a prominent figure in the picture It was strange, that he told me, he did not meet me last Friday or recommend to me the young Artist from Cincinnati— I returned to the House— They were on the point of adjourning— The Supplementary Appropriation Bill for Congressmen and Indians, the Senates amendments to the Second Army Appropriation Bill, the Navy Pension Bill, and the special order, on the public printing, of Congress, were discussed, by Garrett Davis and others— I came home, very unwell, and more—

My indisposition continues and increases— I am all but totally disabled for action or for thought— I passed a nearly sleepless night.— Dr. Thomas much indisposed himself administer to me advice, and medicine, in profusion, and I am barely able, to attend at my Seat, in the House of Representatives.— This morning Allen. G. Thurman 8. Ohio, the Chilicothe District moved to discharge the committee of the whole, from the consideration
of the Bill relating to the payment of Claims against the Government this was carried: the Bill was taken up in the House, passed and sent to the Senate.— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Lynn Boyd Chairman, upon a joint resolution from the Senate regulating the printing for the two Houses of Congress. A perpetual source of wrangling between the Democratic and Whig Parties each underbiding the other for economy, and each lavish without stinct to fatten their favourite printers with jobs Garrett Davis finished his Speech commenced yesterday and was answered by Thomas— H. Bayly, with an hour of dull invective and self-laudation— Rathbun emitted a Speech, against speech-making and moved the Committee to rise, for a resolution to close the debate this day, which was done. He moved in the House the hour of 1 P.M. Dromgoole moved 5. Cobb 3. both rejected Cobb moved to lay the resolution on the Table—lost— Rathbun’s hour of 1. prevailed Committee again Boyd in the Chair. Henley, Bayly, Garrett, Davis, Douglass, and McKay, moved amendments, all rejected and the resolution as it came from the Senate was reported to the House, engrossed passed, the reconsideration refused 100. to 55— Houston of Alabama asked to be excused from voting; but was refused— J. J. McDowel asked to be excused gave silly reasons, and withdrew his request. Committee of the whole again Dunlap Chairman Thurman Holmes, Jenkins, debated till the committee rose and the House adjourned— I came home with prostrated strength and passed the evening in convulsive agonies—

I had a disturbed and almost sleepless night, my strength, like theof Virgil, “slides, in liquid lapse away.” My appetite turns to loathing, and without pain, I feel as if all my bones were extracted from my body, yet I write and attend the House. Mr. Yulee, who preached last Sunday morning in the Representative Hall was this day introduced to me He is of the New Jerusalem Church, or in other words a Swedenborgian, to me, the most senseless of infatuated mysticism— I have received a pamphlet by Thomas. H. Perry, Professor of Mathematics in the United States Navy upon the correspondence, of natural things to Spiritual, republished from the New Jerusalem Magazine upon Gealogy— At the House Jacob— S— Yost, from the Committee on Engraving reported a resolution for five thousand extra copies of the map accompanying document 211. relating to mineral Lands on Lake Superior. Adopted— Houston of Alabama afterwards moved to reconsider this resolution, but failed— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union. Dunlap Chairman, on Charles. S. Benton’s 17. New York report from a select committee of a joint resolution, directing the manner, of procuring the printing for the two Houses, of Congress. The committee soon rose, and a resolution passed to close the debate at 1. this day, accordingly at one oclock the voting commenced and the resolutions were adopted— Committee of Conference, on the conflicting votes, on the second Army Appropriation Bill The Conferees appointed were McKay, Black, of South Carolina and Ashmun— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the Bill from the Judiciary committee to increase the duties or in other words the Salary of the Attorney General, from $4500 to $6000 a year— Debate but no conclusion— I failed to get the floor, and came home, heart and head sick—

A disturbed and desolate night— Prostrate desponding—weary of existence, but never ceasing praise to God for the numberless blessings of his Providence throughout my life, and so many of which I still enjoy— Never ceasing to pray for his sustaining hand through the dispensations yet in reserve, and especially for the controul of my own heart, for patience and resignation— I still attend the Meetings of the House and yesterday made several attempts to get the floor without success— This morning Douglass’ motion to close debate on the Bill to increase the duties of the Attorney General in one hour, modified to 1. oclock was adopted was adopted— Joseph R. Ingersoll offered a joint Resolution argumentative and verbose, advising the President to propose to Mexico a Negotiation for Peace, and hinting an arbitration; but the House would not receive it— The Bill to increase the duties that is the powers and salary of the Attorney General was riddled in Union Committee, debated will one oclock then striped of its noxious parts, and loaded with others, by successive amendments; a substitute offered by Tibbatts was at last reported to the House, and then at the motion of Roberts laid on the table— Its only real object was to give an enormous increase of power, and of profit to the Office of Attorney General— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Richard Brodhead 10. Pennsylvania, Chairman— Bill for erection and repair of certain defensive fortifications Tibbatts moved to authorize the President to suspend all works of fortification during the Mexican War— Long speech of Henry J. Seaman 2 New York. Amendments were proposed by Giles of Maryland, Elias. B Holmes 28. New York and Joseph. R. Ingersoll to refer the Pea Patch question to Chief Justice Taney— Also by W. W. Campbell Andrew York and Grinnell Massachusetts— Hungerford moved an amendment for Sackets Harbor. Committee rose. Letter from Post Master P. M. Butler about treating with Camanchee Indians— Burts motion and adjourn—

I have an occasional, or rather annual outscouring to go through, usually in the month of July, in which I was born, and its operation, has been this year more severe than usual but I hope the crisis of it has now passed, and I am this day convalescent, for the present— I received this morning a Letter from James. R. Snowden, Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Treasury Office Harrisburg, 20th. July 1846, enclosing a draft on the Bank of Pennsylvania, of 20. dolls. in favor of Nathaniel Chick or? order, which he had requested, should be forwarded to me, but Chick did not appear this day— At the House, Lynn Boyd, moved a joint resolution that the hour for adjournment of the Session on the 19th. of August, should be noon adopted— Armistead Burts resolution moved yesterday, was for a select committee of five to enquire into and report on the legality and proprietary of the expenditures of Butler, and Lewis Commissioner to the Camanchees and other Tribes of Indians— The resolution was adopted, and afterwards reconsidered, and laid on the Table— Butler is an ex-Governor of South Carolina. McKay, had made some free remarks, on the extravagance of the expenditures of these Commissioners, whereupon they bristled up, and through Burt, called for this Committee of investigation and enquiry— It was a South Carolina Dragooning, and whipped McKay back into the traces— Joseph. R. Ingersoll moved to suspend the rules for a joint resolution recommending to the President, to negotiate for Peace with Mexico; fudge suspension of rules refused. Numerous reports received from Committees. D. P. King, moved a resolution to allow each Member $30. for the long and $15. for the short Session—instead of Stationary. Laid on the table. Warehousing Bill received from the Senate— Question of its commitment, postponed till Monday— Private Bills— Eighty-five passed— 93. objected to and passed over. Committee of the whole rose and the House adjourned at three—

Recovering from the total prostration of my bodily faculties, and as total of the energies of the mind I endeavour once more to assume some useful occupation— In vain— The House confined itself almost entirely to the consideration of Private Bills taking up first, the Bills from the Senate reported yesterday in committee of the whole— Among these was a Bill for the relief of Amos Kendall; upon whose claim there have been repeated judicial decisions against him and on which he was for years within prison bounds The last decision of a political Supreme Court, was in his favor, and the people paid the piper. There was also a Bill granting a small sum, to Mrs. Pike, widow of General Zebulon Montgomery Pike killed in an invasion of upper Canada, during the last War with Great Britain—but this grant was for services of exploration, in 1805. and 1806 after the purchase of Louisiana Daniel of North Carolina Chairman of the Committee of Claims opposed it; tooth and nail so did Atkinson of Virginia and Houston of Alabama, who moved to lay it on the table— But it was supported by Gordon and Culver and passed 88 to 64. The day closed with a Bill for the settlements of accounts of John Crowell an Indian agent which was read third time, but on the question of its passage, no quorum . . . and after an inffectual motion for a call of the House, they adjourned before one oclock— I went into the Senate Chamber and heard Webster speak two hours against the Bill, to reduce the Tariff of 1842. The Hall was crowded and I left him speaking after three— Mr. John Connell was here this evening

The forty-ninth anniversary of my wedding day— The Revd G. T. Flanders, a Universalist from St Louis Missouri preached this morning, in the Hall of Representatives— His forms of worship are those of the Congregational Church, but his mode of prayer seemed to me not quite sufficiently devotional— He gave out two Hymns, from the collection, used by the Unitarians in this City, and they were sung, by persons of the Auditory, present which was not large. The text of Mr. Flanders, was Genesis 1.28. “And God blessed them, and God said unto them, be fruitful, and multiply and replenish the earth, and subdue it”— The preacher probably did not know that this was precisely the passage, cited by me in the House on the 2nd. of January last, as the primitive foundation of our title to the Oregon Territory. The doctrine deduced from it, by Mr. Flanders was that man, by the Constitution of his nature was created a laborious animal, that the condition, of his existence in the Garden of Eden—before the fall, was labor— He gave notice that the Revd. Mr. Yulee would preach at the Unitarian Church this afternoon at 4. oclock and he himself this evening at 8. There was no afternoon Service at St John’s. I wished to attend at the Unitarian Church at 4 but was forbidden owing to the intense heat of the weather I did attend at 8. and heard Mr. Flanders from John 8.32 “And ye shall know the truth and the truth shall make you free—” But what is true? The Sermon was a very earnest discourse, to prove the universal salvation of all mankind, [“]as in Adam all die, so in Christ shall all be made alive—” I hope so, and still find consolation in public Worship—

Fahrenheit 82. the temperature of the Night. Life seems returning to me, and with it the longing for the Potomac bath and swim But I have not the command of my own limbs; and cannot go— Nor can I yet keep along with the current of my correspondence or of the public business with which I am concerned— I answered three Letters from a man named Sizer enquiring concerning a petition presented, originally by Baker and against which the Committee of Claims reported last March— I have received also a Letter from J Bigelow Agent for the heirs of Francis Eagan, in whose favor there is a Bill, before the House, and a report from the judiciary Committee— Also a printed Circular from Wiley and Putnam 26. July 1846. N.Y enclosing another to the Secretary of State of the several states, proposing to purchase public Documents and books for the Managers of the British Museum At the House the Speaker announced the Warehousing bill as the special order, of the day, but it was postponed till next Wednesday and a Resolution was adopted to close the debate on the fortification bill at noon this day— The Bill was immediately taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Orville Hungerford in the Chair. Ashmun made an hour speech against the President for the War with Mexico. McKay took no notice of it but talked about the fortifications. Burt wasted some ten minutes and 12 o’clock came. Numerous amendments were proposed and rejected— That offered by Joseph R. Ingersoll authorizing the President to settle for the Pea patch Island was adopted and the Bill passed— The Postage Bill was taken up and debated till for lack of a quorum the committee rose and adjourned. I went into the Senate Chamber and heard Mr. Jarnagin—

The remnant of my life is a long disease. A succession of complaints disable me for all active exertion of body or of mind and I no sooner seem to recover from one, than I am stricken down by another.— I am especially deprived of that, continuity of application to particular subjects indispensable for the transaction of business public or private The course of Legislation carried on by the present administration of the Government is vicious and pernicious, but is sustained by the will or the acquiescence of the People— The Nation is plunged into an unjust and wicked War—and not only submits to it, but wages it as if it were a War of Self defence— I still receive numerous applications from individuals to assist them in the prosecution of their claims, but am often unable to follow them up with that unintermitting attention without which it is impossible to carry them through— At the House, Strong and Culver moved Resolutions concerning the distribution of documents to the new members which failed for lack of two-thirds majority to suspend the rules— The Postage bill was taken up in Union Committee— David. S. Reid. 3. North Carolina in the Chair, with a long rigmarole episode about the resignation of W. H. Haywood a Senator from that State.— Briggs, Barringer, Dobbin Dockery discoursed about it and about it— All a-propos of the Post Office Bill, till soon after 2, oclock the Committee rose and the House adjourned— I went into the Senate Chamber where John— M— Niles Senator from Connecticut was blowing the last blast, against the Tariff bill, in vain.— The engrossment of the bill had been carried by the casting vote of the Vice-President, George. M Dallas and the Bill passed 28. to 29. We had evening visits from Mr. John Connell and also from Lieutenant George Thom

I received 26 Letters printed all of one tenor but signed by different individuals from Nantucket invoking my influence in support of the Bill to indemnify the Sufferers by French spoliations before 1800— The appeal to my feelings is most impressive—but the day, of my strength is past, and an atmosphere at 90 degrees of Fahrenheit annihilating— A Scotchman by the name of Stewart was here.— A benevolent undertaker to promote the migration of his poor Countrymen to the United States and soliciting money for himself, which I declined to give— At the House the new Tariff Bill was received from the Senate, with an amendment striking out, the 9th. Section. The special order of the day, the Warehouse Bill was postponed till tomorrow— Call of the House 211 answered, 10. absent, 4 vacancies— The question to suspend the special order, and take up the Message from the Senate was carried 108. to 100. Winthrop claimed that it could be carried only by a two-thirds vote— The Speaker said it was too late to raise the objection— Winthrop appealed and the appeal was laid on the table 102 to 98— Stewart moved to lay the Bill, with the Senates amendment on the table, lost 96 to 113— A second motion to lay the bill on the table was rejected 99 to 113— And the concurrence with the amendment of the Senate was carried 115 to 92. And thus perishes the Tariff of 1842— Carried by a majority of one. John White then Speaker of the House and now repealed by the casting vote of George. M. Dallas, Vice President of the United States and President of the Senate— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union upon the Post Office Bill, debated till of the 210 who had voted on the Tariff Bill, there was not a quorum of 113. left, and after some convulsive throes—the Committee rose and the House adjourned—no evening visitors—

My colleague Benjamin Thompson from the 4th. Congressional District Massachusetts, put into my hands a Letter from Elijah Clark of Brighton to him stating that he had forwarded to me a pension claim of Lydia Weston, to which no answer had been received— It is one of many cases received from Mr. Clark and the circumstance of which have escaped from my memory— I received also a Letter from John Barrett—Waggoners, Ripple Post Office, Adams County, Ohio—soliciting for a pension claim of an old widow named Mary Taylor, daughter of William Flood or Floid a Revolutionary Soldier and Mr. Barrett encloses a Letter of 3. June 1846, to him from the Commissioner of Pensions importing that Mrs. Mary Taylor, has no claim at all— At the House the special order of the day was again postponed, and after Thomasson had introduced a bill to establish a post road from this City to Cumberland the Columbia river in the Oregon Territory, Hopkins new Post Office bill, was received in Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union David— S. Reid—3. North Carolina in the Chair— A snarl of debate followed upon swarming amendments till Hopkins took a vote upon his substitute, for the whole bill, which was rejected 81. to 96— Then Owen moved to reconsider that rejection— The Committee had risen for lack of a quorum, and been discharged from consideration of the bill— Rathbun moved to lay Owen’s motion on the table— This was carried 99. to 84—and Dromgoole as Speaker decided that it carried the bill, with it— Bill about Java Coffee and duties on Spanish Vessels—passed with an amendment from the Senate— French spoliation Bill— Outbreak of Allen. G. Thurman of Ohio against it— He had not finished when the Committee rose and the House adjourned— We had no evening visitors—

I received a Letter from Rufus. W— Griswold dated yesterday at Philadelphia, enclosing a printed notice of 3. Octavo pages, headed John-Quincy-Adams—and asking copies of my Oration at Cincinnati, and my Speech against the admission of Texas— At the House instead of resuming the consideration of the French spoliation bill; they went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the Warehousing system bill, which was the special order of the day— McKay moved a Call of the House. 115 answered to their names Hilliard of Alabama, opened the debate by moving to strike out the first section, except the clause, and he spoke an hour against the Bill and about the Tariff of 1842, and its repeal just consummated, for which he voted though he had many objections to the new bill— Truman Smith of Connecticut followed with a heavy and bitter invective against the repeal of the Tariff of 1842— Thomas— H— Bayly and W. W. Payne of Alabama consumed two successive hours in railing not in good fat terms, but in hectoring common place, against the Tariff of 1842. Andrew Stewart of Pennsylvania replied to them both in a tone somewhat like their own, though much more spirited. John. G. Chapman 3. Maryland took the floor— The Committee rose and the House adjourned— William— H. Haywood junior published this day in the National Intelligencer a notice to the People of North-Carolina, that he intends to publish in a few days an Address to them in justification of his recent resignation of his Seat as a Member of the Senate of the United States of America: Again no evening visitors—
